sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight, here are your headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russia strikes the vital port of Odessa in the south with new hypersonic missiles hitting hotels and a shopping centre.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: President Zelensky calls for an end to the blockade of Odessa, saying that targeting supply lines threatens the global food supply.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Western allies say Russia is to blame for a massive cyber attack that hit Ukraine just hours before the invasion began.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And the UK's Prince Charles opens Parliament standing in for the Queen who missed the occasion for the first time in 59 years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey, glad you could join me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russia has pounded the southern port city of Odessa overnight with rocket attacks destroying five buildings and killing at least one person.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian officials say that Russian forces used hypersonic missiles against non-military targets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Five people are reported to have been injured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: As the attack took place, European Council President Charles Michel was in the city meeting with the Ukrainian Prime Minister for talks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, our international correspondent Anneliese Borges is in the southern port city of Odessa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We can cross over to her now. Good evening to you, Anneliese. Good to see you. Of course, you are there in Odessa, a city which was struck by Russian missiles last night, reportedly new hypersonic missiles at that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Talk us through what happened, Angles.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Indeed, two main areas were hit here in Odessa on Monday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The port was hit in the afternoon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: A customs office was destroyed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: One person was killed there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And, of course course that shopping mall was hit later in the evening from where I'm standing here we could hear the loud bang and earlier today we drove to the site to see the damage sustained by the building which is almost completely destroyed now I spoke to the mayor of Odessa about these multiple strikes here in this city over the last few days and he Gennady Truhanov said that these strikes are proof that Russia is targeting civilian infrastructure he said for example that that mall was very popular among Odessa residents that that's where they took their children to play, to eat at restaurants. He also said that he is concerned there could be more violence here in Odessa over the next few days, because he knows of the historic value of this city to Russia, but also because of its strategic location. If Russia was to capture Odessa, they could indeed move their troops further west from Mykolaiv and build this corridor all the way to Transnistria, which is a pocket of territory in Moldova, which is currently controlled by Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: When asked whether he believed that what happened in Mariupol could happen here in Odessa, the mayor said that indeed he is concerned that Odessa could fall but that he and the residents here are doing everything in their power to avoid that. I asked if he had a message to Vladimir Putin, a person he was accused of being close to in the past, and this is what the mayor of Odessa had to say. I would like to say to putin listen nobody believes in it anymore nobody believes you stop it pull off your mask today you represent a different country you are a country of aggression today without any reason you invaded a sovereign state you are killing people here even children you are destroying everything we built here savagely you are destroying everything in Ukraine. Stop the war in Ukraine. Withdraw your troops.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So a defiant message there from the mayor of Odessa where you are, Anneliese. We've

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: also been hearing from President Zelensky today directly talking about Odessa as well, talking about Black Sea ports and how bombardment and blockades of those strategic areas could also threaten the global food supply.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: What more can you tell us about that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Indeed, millions of tonnes of grains, wheat and corn are currently stuck here in Odessa, according to authorities, but also according to the UN and in other parts of the region, stranded because of Russia's blockade of Black Sea ports. And this is already affecting food prices worldwide. They are feeling the impact in places like Sri Lanka, Lebanon and African countries. And things could get worse. Why?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Because before the war, Russia and Ukraine accounted for almost 30% of the global wheat exports, 60% of global sunflower supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And of course, because of the conflict, all that is disrupted with millions of tons of grains now stuck here in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The World Food Bank is saying that the prices could go up. They could jump some 37 percent over the next few months. And of course, that is going to push millions of people into poverty and potentially into malnutrition. And authorities here in Ukraine have repeatedly said that that is proof that Russia is waging a war not only against this country, but against the entire world. Helena? Our international correspondent Anneliese Borges there in the southern port city

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: of Odessa in Ukraine. Anneliese, thank you. Well, tracking the latest developments across Ukraine is our correspondent Sasha Vakulina, and she joins me here in the studio. Good to have you with us once again, Sasha.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yesterday, we were hearing about the situation around the Azovstal steelworks plant in Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We were hearing that Russian forces are continuing their attacks, possibly preparing to actually storm those steelworks. Today, we're hearing that there could be around 100 civilians still trapped inside that is despite reports to the contrary do we know what is going on here not really we've heard it only today after all those reports about all the women and children and elderly being evacuated although maybe among those civilians there are also men who were not evacuated we did not hear that point about all those convoys over the weekend apart from the hundred civilians who are still there at Azovstal, there are over a thousand of Ukrainian defenders who are still there. Many of them are wounded. This afternoon, they released some pictures of the wounded soldiers, those defenders who are in those tunnels of Azovstal and the conditions for medical support and medical assistance that they have, or we should say they do not have there in the tunnels of Azovstal. Indeed, the assault of Azovstal continues and today there was heavy storming of it with the with the storming back by tanks artillery and the and the missiles the storming operation continues as it is now but what we've heard from Ukrainian Defenders is that they're still not going to surrender for Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So we carry on with the current situation of around 100 civilians, more than 1,000 Ukrainian defendants still being in those tunnels of Azovstal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We've also heard today actually from the Pentagon in the US that the strike that we saw overnight in Odessa may have been an attempt to actually thwart operations in the east of the country, despite that happening in the south. How could that work strategically?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That could theoretically work somehow, given that over the past 24 hours, Russian forces in the east did not really have any significant gains across all the front line of Ukraine. At the same time, there was an interesting UK defence ministry intelligence update where they say that Russia underestimated quite a lot of Ukrainian resistance and saying that Russia's invasion plan highly likely to have been based on the mistaken assumption that it would encircle limited resistance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And this is not what we have been seeing for over two months of this war since Russia invaded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: for over two months of this war since Russia invaded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The Institute for the Study of War, another think tank that is analysing daily the situation there on the ground, also said that Russian troops in Ukraine continue to display low morale and poor discipline all across the front lines, including that in the east and the south of the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: When it comes to this southeastern corridor, the city of Zaporizhia, there was a particular line here saying that those forces those force that deployed in the police area reportedly are experiencing very low moral and psychological conditions they complain about the ineffectiveness operations in the area frequently abuse alcohol and shooting their own vehicles in order to avoid going to the front line this is according to the Institute for the study of war something I did want to ask you about Sasha is Ukraine's strategy here because we talk a lot about the Russian war strategy but I wonder as this war continues has Ukraine's aims, its goals changed at all?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We've heard it for the first time from Ukraine's authorities today. There was foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba who said in an interview to the Financial Times that indeed Ukraine has upgraded its war aims and is now looking to push Russian forces out of the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Out of the country means, of course, those occupied before territories of Donbass and Crimea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Both parts were annexed in 2014.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This is the first time we hear such a statement from Ukrainian authorities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Of course, it is based on the fact that Western allies keep supplying weapons, and this does not stop, particularly those heavy weapons that Ukrainian forces really needed so much for the front all over the country, trying to resist and to defend and also to go into counteroffensive against Russian forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And when the war started, the negotiations between Ukraine and Russia also started.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: You remember, just two or three weeks into the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And then we've heard from Ukrainian negotiators that they can't really go on with diplomatic solution because the diplomatic solution will depend on how the fighting goes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And now we do see that in the battle for Donbass, Russia has not taken Donbass, as it claimed for the second stage of this war. And this is why these aims and the targets for Kiev, Ukrainian authorities might be changing now, because with the resistance, with the defense, also with counter offenses and with the supplies and help by Western allies, they can see that they're not only defending and resisting where they are in the current situation but they can also push it a little bit further because as of the peace talks a few weeks ago what we heard is that Ukraine was asking Russia to go back to those borders where they were on the 23rd of February right before this full-scale invasion as you say a very significant statement one of the first times that we've heard it in fact during this war from Koleba Sasha Vakulina as ever thank you for that well nearly a week on from the proposal to ban Russian oil imports as part of a sixth round of sanctions and the EU is still trying to find agreement Hungary continues to block the package saying that the effect on its economy would be catastrophic now a visit by Commission President Ursula von der Leyen to Budapest on Monday doesn't appear to have appeased fears.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So we can go straight over now to Brussels and we can speak to Shona Murray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Shona, we've just heard there from both of our correspondents about the mounting death toll in Ukraine as this war continues to go on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But, I mean, a week on from these oil sanctions being proposed from the EU, there doesn't really seem to be much movement. Is this a stalemate?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, we don't know that. I mean, there is still hope. I suppose the feeling is it can't be that the EU doesn't pass this sixth round of sanctions. It's so important because of the impact that oil has on the Russian war machine. But indeed, you're right there. It's been important because of the impact that oil has on the russian war machine but indeed you're right there it's been a week since the eu published the proposals for this the sixth sanctions package nobody thought it was going to be easy but i think there was a bit more optimism that it would pass a little bit sooner or at least progress would be stronger now your news caught up with the uk ambassador to the EU, Ambassador Tsensov, and he called on countries like Hungary to be human and to accept the sacrifices that would be required for such monumental sanctions like these.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Once again, we expect that decision makers in Hungary, in other countries, they're human. They're humans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: They understand what is going on in Ukraine. They themselves, they could see the level of atrocities around Kyiv and in other cities. So, in order to stop Russia, I think EU member states, they should be also ready for certain sacrifices, including economic sacrifices.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Ambassador Shentzoff there speaking to Euronews. Shona, we know that the spanner in the works here is Hungary. And you do have to wonder how could the EU eventually deal with Hungary when it is clearly weighing here on foreign policy decisions?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Yes, you know, it's very interesting, Helena, because obviously member states in the EU want to show that there is unity and that there is substance and that all 27 member states want to push ahead with these sanctions. Viktor Orban himself hasn't said that Hungary will block the sanctions, but that they're looking for a much longer lead in time and possibly a lot of money. There's been questions as to whether Viktor Orban is using the situation in order for Hungary to have its recovery fund money, 7 billion euro, unlocked by the EU. And you're right, I mean it's a very difficult situation. Having said that, speaking to ambassadors and diplomats and so on over the past week, everybody understands the situation is difficult for Hungary because it's landlocked.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Also countries like Slovakia and the Czech Republic, they're in a difficult situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But really very little progress has been made, despite the fact that Ursula von der Leyen herself was in Budapest last night.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: There was supposed to be a video conference today, which was cancelled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: All we can say is tomorrow EU ambassadors are meeting again and there have been bilateral meetings. So the hope is that eventually this does pass but we don't know exactly what the terms are the price. Helena. All right Shona Murray bringing us up to date as we hold our breath and wait on a sixth round of EU sanctions. Shona, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Hello again. Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He was one of the most famous artists of the 20th century and she was one of the most famous actresses. When Andy Warhol decided to paint Marilyn Monroe, the result was an iconic work called Shot Sage Blue Marilyn. Well, it's now garnered even more fame by breaking world auction records, as Richard Cady reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And so, ladies and gentlemen, we come to an iconic portrait of Marilyn Monroe by American pop art visionary Andy Warhol has gone under the hammer for a shade under 185 million euros at Christie's, becoming the most expensive 20th century artwork ever sold at a public auction. Warhol's 1964 silkscreen image entitled Shot Sage Blue Marilyn, produced in 1964, two years after the death of the glamorous Hollywood star, sold in just under four minutes in a crowded room at Christie's headquarters in Manhattan, beating Pablo Picasso's Woman of Algiers, which sold for 170,000 euros in 2015.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We did sell the most expensive painting of the 20th century.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I'm very proud of that and along with my team I think everyone is very proud of that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This is a big achievement that is not on me but just on Warhol and Marilyn. And if you think about Warhol prices, the Warhol record was at $103 million for the silver car crash.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This almost doubled it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And again, 20th century works of art, American works of art, it's the highest price ever paid, close to $200 million.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: price ever paid close to 200 million dollars. The proceeds of this particular silk screen will go to the Thomas and Doris Amman Foundation in Zurich which aims to help children with health care and educational programs. Richard Cady Euronews. You're up to date I'll see you soon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The agenda for the coming year as he delivered the Queen's speech at the opening of Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Charles, standing in for his mother, Queen Elizabeth, who for the first time in 59 years wasn't able to attend, outlined Boris Johnson's proposals on education, energy and the economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The Prime Minister heads into the new Parliament session on the back of disappointing local election results, a cost of living crisis and a growing row over the Northern Ireland Protocol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But this year's policy agenda did appear to be wide-ranging and for more on it now we can cross over to our reporter, Tyege Enright in London. Tyege, good to see you. Many issues touched on in this speech but which ones would you say, which policy issues were the most hotly anticipated?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, it's the soaring cost of living, particularly when it comes to energy bills, which is the hot button political issue of the moment, not just here, but in most of the developed world. Certainly mentioned as a priority in this speech, but little hint as to what concrete new measures could be forthcoming, although Boris Johnson, the Prime Minister, did later say that new measures would be outlined in the next couple of days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But, you know, these speeches, the setting out of the government's agenda for the year to come, for the Parliament to come at the beginning of a new session of Parliament, are always really about headlines rather than gritty details. And a lot of what we heard is what were repeats, you know, the government's longstanding pledge to equalise unequal parts of the UK, to revitalise depressed town centres. They're still apparently looking to find opportunities to seize arising from Britain leaving the European Union. And then those hardy perennials which appeal to Boris Johnson's right-wing base within the Conservative Party, limiting the right to protest, particularly when it comes to environmental protests and cracking down on migrants coming over from France in small boats.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But really, as you touched on there in your intro, what will be on many people's minds is the fact that this was a Queen's speech without the Queen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We know that her health has been deteriorating in recent months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: She's missed several events, although the very last minute nature of this change of running order, change of royal delivering the Queen's speech will raise many concerns. In a few weeks' time, we're going to have celebrations to mark the 70th anniversary of Queen Elizabeth's ascension to the throne. And the question in many people's minds is, will she be able to participate in the way which has been planned?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Quite a moment, quite a question there, of course, as well, Ty. So the Parliament, nevertheless, has had its annual opening there in the UK, but, of course, in Northern Ireland, off the back of the parliamentary elections, still waiting to get Stormont up and running.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We understand that both the leader of the DUP and Michelle O'Neill this morning spoke to Boris Johnson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What more do we know after those conversations?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, I think it's fair to summarise that we are now looking into a new chapter of political impasse in Northern Ireland, where I think people have become accustomed to their government being suspended as much as being at work, and a new series of political repeats, which we're going to hear over and over again in the coming months. The unionists in the DUP, which had been the biggest party in Northern Ireland, no longer is after the recent elections, urging the government here in London to address its concerns about the Northern Ireland Protocol before it will entertain the notion of entering into government now as a potentially junior party to Sinn Féin, the biggest nationalist party. The message from its leader, Michelle O'Neill, is let's get on with forming that new government, this time with us at the helm. And she summarised that the Northern Irish public can't be a pawn in the British government's game of chicken with the EU. And that, I think, pretty much hits it on the nail there. There have been warnings here over the past week that the UK will tear up the Northern Ireland protocol. Now, many people are saying, where have we heard that before? We had been expecting it to be mentioned in the Queen's speech today, but it really barely got a mention. It simply talked about the importance of maintaining the internal economic links between the various parts of the UK, perhaps because reportedly some voices at Cabinet urged more caution, warning that it could spark a trade war between the UK and the EU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And at this particularly precipitous economic moment, that's the last thing that those voices would like to see. All right, some of those hardy perennial issues coming back once again, as you put it, Taig Enright. Taig, reporting there from London, thank you.
